newsitem.title: BELARUS: Lukashenko sets parliament deadline to approve deal.
newsitem.headline: Lukashenko sets parliament deadline to approve deal.

text.p: Belarussian President Alexander Lukashenko on Friday gave his reluctant parliament a two-hour deadline to approve a peace deal ending their confrontation over a referendum to increase his powers.
Lukashenko, addressing parliament, called on it to approve the accord by a two-thirds majority by 6 p.m. (1600 GMT) with no amendments or conditions attached.

"I must state that the referendum will go ahead on November 24 and as head of state I will do everything I can to ensure that the will of the people will be binding within the framework of the agreement," he said.

Refering to the overnight peace deal mediated by Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, he said: "Today's decision is final. This is our last meeting before the referendum. Let us go to the referendum together and submit to the will of the people."

He spoke after deputies, the majority of whom oppose Lukashenko, attacked the agreement as a sellout. In return for parliament dropping attempts to remove Lukashenko from office, the president agreed that the referendum should only be consultative rather than binding.
It was not clear what the consequences would be if the deputies refused to back the accord by the required majority of 132 our of 199 members.
